title: Synthetic Recap
body:
DALLAS (AP) — On a night where the final score read 113-110 in favor of the Minnesota Timberwolves, the numbers on the stat sheet told a more profound, historic story. This was not merely a road victory; this was the Kevin Garnett game, a virtuoso performance for the ages.

Garnett, the lithe and ferociously intense forward, was simply unguardable. He erupted for a career-high and franchise-record 47 points, a staggering figure that left the Dallas Mavericks scrambling for answers. Every turn-around jumper, every powerful drive to the rim, was another brushstroke in his masterpiece. He was not just scoring; he was imposing his will, pouring in 21 points in the third quarter alone to seize control of a tight contest.

While Stephon Marbury provided a crucial 22-point, 11-assist backbone, and Tom Gugliotta’s 16 points and 16 rebounds were essential, they were powerful accompaniment to Garnett’s solo. The Mavericks, led by a valiant 25-point effort from Michael Finley and a 22-point, 13-assist double-double from Steve Nash, fought tooth and nail. They refused to be blown out, but they had no ultimate answer for the force wearing number 21 in white and blue.

In the game’s final, breathless moments, with the outcome hanging in the balance, every possession was funneled through Garnett. He was the catalyst, the finisher, the undeniable heart of the Timberwolves’ effort. When the final horn sounded, his 47 points stood not just as a personal best, but as a landmark moment for a young superstar and his franchise. It was a performance so monumental that the final score felt almost secondary to the singular, breathtaking show Garnett put on.
